events.title: Birth of Alan Hovhaness
events.summary: Alan Hovhaness was born as Alan Vaness Chakmakjian in Somerville, Massachusetts to Armenian and Scottish parents. His family moved to Arlington, Massachusetts when he was five, due to concerns about discrimination against Armenians in Somerville.
events.fun_version: Alan Hovhaness, originally named Alan Vaness Chakmakjian, was born in Somerville, Massachusetts to Armenian and Scottish parents. His family, concerned about discrimination against Armenians in Somerville, decided that living there might not be the best idea. So, when Alan turned five, they packed up their bags and moved to Arlington, Massachusetts.

events.title: First Composition
events.summary: At the age of four, Hovhaness wrote his first composition, a cantata inspired by a song of Franz Schubert. His early interest in music was evident, despite concerns from his family regarding his financial future in the arts.
events.fun_version: At the tender age of four, Hovhaness composed his first masterpiece, a cantata that was basically his way of saying, "Hey, Schubert! Hold my juice box!” While most kids were perfecting their skills in hide-and-seek, Hovhaness was crafting symphonies, leaving his family concerned about his financial future in the arts and wondering if their son would ever master the art of balancing a future in music with a day job.

events.title: Piano Lessons
events.summary: Hovhaness's parents supported his musical pursuits by arranging for his first piano lessons with a neighborhood teacher. He later continued his studies with Adelaide Proctor and Heinrich Gebhard.
events.fun_version: Hovhaness's parents were like the ultimate music managers, pulling strings behind the scenes to land their kid the best piano lessons in the neighborhood with a local teacher. He later continued his studies with the greats, Adelaide Proctor and Heinrich Gebhard.

events.title: Decision to Pursue Composition
events.summary: By age 14, Hovhaness made the decision to devote himself to composition after experiencing a range of musical influences, including Baptist hymns and the works of Armenian composer Gomidas Vartabed.
events.fun_version: By the time he was 14, Hovhaness already had so many musical influences that he decided to compose his own tunes. After all, who wouldn't be inspired by Baptist hymns and Armenian compositions? It’s like mixing a Sunday service with an Armenian dinner—spiritual and deliciously complex!

events.title: Graduation and Study at Tufts
events.summary: Hovhaness graduated from high school in 1929 and subsequently studied at Tufts University. He later studied under Frederick Converse at the New England Conservatory of Music, where he won a composition prize in 1932.
events.fun_version: Hovhaness graduated high school in 1929. After that, he decided Tufts University was the place to be. Then he trained under Frederick Converse at the New England Conservatory of Music, where he snagged a composition prize in 1932.

events.title: Trip to Finland
events.summary: In July 1934, Hovhaness traveled to Finland with his first wife, Martha Mott Davis, to meet the composer Jean Sibelius, with whom he corresponded for twenty years.
events.fun_version: In July 1934, Hovhaness traveled to Finland with his first wife, Martha, to meet the legendary composer Jean Sibelius with whom he corresponded for twenty years. It must have been quite a fascinating discussion about symphonies in such a frosty environment!

events.title: Concerto for Cello and Orchestra
events.summary: A vibrant and lyrical work that highlights the cello's expressive capabilities, blending orchestral colors with the soloist's line.
events.fun_version: Imagine a cello throwing a colorful party where it’s the star soloist, blending in with the rest of the orchestra like it's auditioning for a reality show—'The Real Cello Wives of String Instruments.'

events.title: Exile (Symphony No. 1)
events.summary: This symphony explores themes of longing and introspection, presenting a profound emotional landscape through its orchestration.
events.fun_version: This symphony, that deeply explores themes of longing and introspection—like a dog wanting a pizza slice—presents an emotional landscape so rich, it might make you weep more than when you finish the last slice of cake!

events.title: Prelude and Quadruple Fugue
events.summary: This composition for orchestra showcases complex contrapuntal techniques and rich harmonies. It reflects Hovhaness's unique voice and dedication to symphonic form.
events.fun_version: This symphony for orchestra is such a brain teaser that even the notes need a map! But don’t worry - the orchestra still managed to hit the right notes. It’s a cacophony of creativity, where Hovhaness showcases his heart and dedication to complex contrapuntal techniques and symphonic form!

events.title: Alleluia and Fugue
events.summary: This composition combines joyful alleluias with intricate fugal structures, showcasing Hovhaness's blend of sacred and classical music idioms.
events.fun_version: This musical masterpiece mixes joyful alleluias with fugal structures so intricate, they could make a Rubik's Cube look like child's play! It's like Hovhaness took a dash of heaven and stirred it with a stick of classical music, creating a symphony that's holier than a Sunday School choir on caffeine!

events.title: Church Organist Position
events.summary: Hovhaness became the organist for the St. James Armenian Apostolic Church in Watertown, Massachusetts, where he developed a deep interest in Armenian culture and music for nearly a decade. This position played a significant role in shaping his musical identity and style, allowing him to immerse himself in Armenian traditions.
events.fun_version: Hovhaness spent almost ten years as the organist for the St. James Armenian Apostolic Church in Watertown, Massachusetts, where he developed a deep interest in Armenian culture and music. He dove headfirst into Armenian traditions!

events.title: Destruction of Early Works
events.summary: During the 1930s and 1940s, Hovhaness famously destroyed many of his early works, claiming to have burned hundreds of pieces due to criticism he received and his desire to make a fresh start in his compositions.
events.fun_version: During the 1930s and 1940s, Hovhaness famously took "spring cleaning" to a whole new level by incinerating his early works, claiming to have burned hundreds of pieces due to the criticism he received and his desire to make a fresh start in his compositions! Apparently, he thought that burning hundreds of pieces would magically transform him from a misunderstood genius into the Mozart of modern times.

events.title: Psalm and Fugue
events.summary: A spiritual piece that intertwines elements of psalmody with fugal writing, offering a reflective and meditative experience.
events.fun_version: A spiritual piece that’s like a choir practice gone wild! Imagine psalmody and fugal writing having a dance-off, creating a reflective and meditative experience that makes you smile as you ponder life’s big questions.

events.title: Scholarship at Tanglewood
events.summary: In 1942, Hovhaness won a scholarship to study under Czech composer Bohuslav Martinů at Tanglewood. During a seminar, he faced criticism from notable composers, which resulted in him leaving Tanglewood prematurely and abandoning his scholarship.
events.fun_version: In 1942, Hovhaness snagged a golden ticket to study under the legendary Czech composer Bohuslav Martinů. During a seminar, he got critiqued by some big-time composers who apparently forgot their own advice: if you can't say something nice, say it with a tuba! Feeling like he was auditioning for the role of 'Most Criticized Composer,' Hovhaness left Tanglewood earlier than planned, abandoning his scholarship like it was a hot potato!

events.title: Lousadzak (Concerto for piano and strings)
events.summary: A unique concerto that merges the piano with string instruments, creating a distinctive sonic palette rich in Armenian influences.
events.fun_version: Imagine a concerto so unique that it merges the piano with string instruments—like a musical blender. You’d think they were trying to make some Armenian smoothie for the ears, but instead, they’ve whipped up a sonic cocktail that your ears never knew they needed!

events.title: Mihr
events.summary: A piece composed for two pianos that emphasizes interplay and dialogue between the instruments, reflecting Hovhaness’s musical philosophy.
events.fun_version: Imagine two pianos having a heated argument about who gets to play the next note! In this lively piece, they don't just play nice — they engage in a duet that could rival any dramatic soap opera, all while reflecting Hovhaness’s musical philosophy.

events.title: Composition of 'Etchmiadzin' Opera
events.summary: In May and June of 1946, Hovhaness composed 'Etchmiadzin', an opera that was commissioned by a local Armenian church, reflecting his continuous exploration of Armenian themes in his music.
events.fun_version: In May and June of 1946, while most folks were busy recovering from the war, Hovhaness was busy composing 'Etchmiadzin'—an opera commissioned by a local Armenian church. This opera is a perfect showcase of his continuous exploration of Armenian themes in his music!

events.title: Prayer of St. Gregory
events.summary: This interlude for trumpet and strings is deeply spiritual and atmospheric, often performed in concert settings, resonating with listeners.
events.fun_version: This interlude for trumpet and strings is like a deeply spiritual and atmospheric vibe check for your ears, often performed in concert settings where even the chairs are swaying with emotion—just be careful not to spill your popcorn!

events.title: Arjuna (Symphony No. 8)
events.summary: A symphonic work that draws on Eastern themes and aesthetics, blending traditional Western orchestration with innovative ideas.
events.fun_version: This symphonic work, inspired by Eastern themes and aesthetics, blends traditional Western orchestration with innovative ideas, creating a delightful culture clash that's both surprising and entertaining.

events.title: Artik Concerto for Horn and String Orchestra
events.summary: This concerto features the horn prominently, weaving lyrical lines with the accompaniment of strings, highlighting a rich harmonic language.
events.fun_version: The horn in this concerto is the star, weaving lyrical lines with the strings in a way that highlights its rich harmonic language—like a musical game of ‘look at me’ as they create a sparkling friendship bracelet of sound!

events.title: St. Vartan Symphony (No. 9)
events.summary: A monumental work that reflects Hovhaness’s connections to Armenian heritage and spirituality through its expansive symphonic form.
events.fun_version: If Hovhaness were a superhero, his cape would be made of Armenian heritage and his symphonies would be so expansive they’d take up more space than your average Thanksgiving dinner. Who knew heritage could be so musical?

events.title: Janabar (Sinfonia Concertante)
events.summary: This work combines multiple solo instruments with orchestral support, showcasing their interplay and creating a vibrant musical conversation.
events.fun_version: This work combines multiple solo instruments with orchestral support, showcasing their interplay like a group of musicians trying to agree on what to order for dinner, creating a vibrant musical conversation that you won't want to miss — unless you hate fun!

events.title: Induction into the National Institute of Arts and Letters
events.summary: In 1951, Hovhaness was inducted into the National Institute of Arts and Letters, recognizing his contributions to the field of music.
events.fun_version: In 1951, Hovhaness waltzed into the National Institute of Arts and Letters like he owned the place! They gave him a standing ovation for his contributions to music, recognizing his remarkable talent in the field.

events.title: Khaldis
events.summary: Designed for piano and multiple trumpets, this energetic piece reveals Hovhaness's inventiveness in orchestration and thematic development.
events.fun_version: Designed for piano and multiple trumpets, this energetic piece reveals Hovhaness's inventiveness in orchestration and thematic development. It’s like a musical party where the piano is the host, and the trumpets just can’t stop trying to steal the spotlight.

events.title: Concerto No. 7
events.summary: An orchestral concerto that emphasizes thematic interplay and showcases Hovhaness's mastery of large-scale orchestral writing.
events.fun_version: Imagine a bunch of musicians trying to outdo each other in an orchestral concerto—a place where themes do a little dance-off showcasing thematic interplay, while Hovhaness, the ultimate maestro, juggles large-scale orchestral writing like it’s a circus act!

events.title: Guggenheim Fellowships
events.summary: Hovhaness received Guggenheim Fellowships in composition during 1953 and 1954, which supported his evolution as a composer and enabled him to explore diverse musical styles and compositions.
events.fun_version: Hovhaness grabbed a couple of Guggenheim Fellowships in 1953 and 1954, which supported his evolution as a composer. With those Fellowships in his pocket, he had the freedom to dive into the wild waters of diverse musical styles, like a kid in a candy store – if the candy store had a symphony orchestra!

events.title: Concerto for Two Pianos and Orchestra
events.summary: This collaboration between two pianos creates a rich texture and lively dialogue, highlighting Hovhaness's innovative approach to concerto form.
events.fun_version: While two pianos collaborate, it’s like a harmonious coffee date where they spill all the tea and create a symphonic masterpiece showcasing Hovhaness’s innovative approach to concerto form – just don’t let them argue over who plays the best solo, or we might need a mediator with a tuning fork!

events.title: Mysterious Mountain (Symphony No. 2)
events.summary: This symphony is a cornerstone of Hovhaness's work, embodying natural imagery and philosophical themes through its expansive orchestration.
events.fun_version: Imagine a symphony so grand that even Mother Nature took out her earplugs! Hovhaness's masterpiece embodies natural imagery and philosophical thoughts like a musical tour guide, where the trees debate life while the birds sing about existential crises.

events.title: Premiere of Symphony No. 2 'Mysterious Mountain'
events.summary: In 1955, Hovhaness's 'Symphony No. 2, Mysterious Mountain' was premiered by Leopold Stokowski in Houston, marking a significant breakthrough in his career.
events.fun_version: In 1955, Hovhaness's 'Symphony No. 2, Mysterious Mountain' was premiered by Leopold Stokowski in Houston, a significant milestone in his career, where rumors say he tried to negotiate with a mountain spirit for a standing ovation!

events.title: Symphony No. 4
events.summary: A profound exploration of human emotion and nature, Symphony No. 4 stands out for its lyrical melodies and rich textures.
events.fun_version: Symphony No. 4 is like that friend who can't stop talking about their feelings. You know, it stands out for its lyrical melodies and rich textures, making you wonder if they’ve started taking poetry classes. Just when you thought you’d get out of a deep conversation, it pulls you back in with emotional range.

events.title: Magnificat
events.summary: This choral piece fuses traditional texts with Hovhaness's distinctive harmonic language, creating an uplifting musical experience.
events.fun_version: This choral piece combines traditional texts with Hovhaness's unique harmonic language, like mixing a classic sandwich with a spicy salsa—an uplifting musical experience that could make even a statue tap its toes!

events.title: Meditation on Orpheus
events.summary: An evocative piece that pays homage to the myth of Orpheus, characterized by a seamless blend of lyrical beauty and harmonic depth.
events.fun_version: An evocative piece that pays homage to the myth of Orpheus—because who doesn't want to hear about a guy who thought a good song would solve everything? It beautifully blends lyrical depth with harmonic richness, much like the music Orpheus would have played at a surprise party!

events.title: Research Trips to Asia
events.summary: From 1959 to 1963, Hovhaness conducted research trips to Asia, including India, where he studied traditional music and collected numerous ragas, significantly influencing his compositions. He received a Fulbright fellowship to further his studies in Carnatic music.
events.fun_version: From 1959 to 1963, Hovhaness conducted research trips to Asia, including India, where he studied traditional music and collected numerous ragas that significantly influenced his compositions. He even managed to snag a Fulbright fellowship to further his studies in Carnatic music, proving that music really is the best excuse to travel.

events.title: Symphony No. 6, Celestial Gate
events.summary: A visionary work that transcends conventional boundaries, exploring celestial themes through expansive orchestral soundscapes.
events.fun_version: A visionary work that transcends conventional boundaries, exploring celestial themes through expansive orchestral soundscapes—kind of like what happens when you accidentally blast your neighbors with classical music while trying to impress that special someone!

events.title: Symphony No. 7, Nanga Parvat
events.summary: Evocative of the majestic mountain, this symphony captures the essence of nature's grandeur through its orchestration and thematic material.
events.fun_version: Picture a mountain so grand that even the squirrels stop to take selfies! This symphony captures the evocative essence of nature's grandeur through its orchestration, but like an overzealous tour guide, it sometimes ends up sounding like a bear playing the tuba instead.

events.title: Symphony No. 11, All Men are Brothers
events.summary: A powerful statement on brotherhood and unity, this symphony combines multiple influences to deliver an uplifting message.
events.fun_version: A symphony so powerful it could unite even the fiercest cats fighting in an alley! This masterpiece blends multiple influences like a well-mixed smoothie, delivering an uplifting message about brotherhood and harmony that’s smoother than a jazz musician on a Sunday morning.

events.title: The Silver Pilgrimage (Symphony No. 15)
events.summary: This work encapsulates a journey of discovery and introspection, combining rich textures and evocative melodies.
events.fun_version: Embarking on a journey of discovery and introspection that’s twisty like a pretzel, this work combines rich textures and melodies so evocative that they might evoke your last snack break!

events.title: Composition of 'Fantasy on Japanese Woodprints'
events.summary: In 1965, Hovhaness composed 'Fantasy on Japanese Woodprints', a concerto for xylophone and orchestra, inspired by his studies of Japanese music.
events.fun_version: In 1965, Hovhaness composed 'Fantasy on Japanese Woodprints', a concerto for xylophone and orchestra, inspired by his studies of Japanese music. He thought, 'Why not combine a xylophone with an orchestra?' And thus, this whimsical piece was born, proving that a bouncy xylophone can indeed inspire a masterpiece!

events.title: Fantasy on Japanese Woodprints
events.summary: A vibrant piece reflecting Hovhaness's fascination with Japanese culture, expressed through innovative instrumental combinations.
events.fun_version: Imagine Hovhaness throwing a sushi party where instead of sushi, he served up a vibrant musical feast that reflects his fascination with Japanese culture through innovative instrumental combinations! Even a samurai would put down his sword and pick up a pair of chopsticks to join in the jam session!

events.title: Fra Angelico
events.summary: Inspired by the Renaissance artist, this work is characterized by ethereal quality and a sense of spiritual uplift.
events.fun_version: Channeling the vibes of a Renaissance artist, this piece is so ethereal it makes clouds look like they're slacking off! It's like a spiritual uplift with a side of 'I really need a nap!'

events.title: Mountains and Rivers without End
events.summary: A chamber symphony that draws on natural imagery, reflecting the beauty of the landscape through intricate instrumentation.
events.fun_version: A chamber symphony that uses natural imagery to reflect the landscape's beauty through intricate instrumentation – because playing music in a field is way better than listening to it in a stuffy concert hall! Just imagine the violins trying to compete with a chorus of chirping crickets.

events.title: Lady of Light
events.summary: This choral work is infused with a sense of hope and spirituality, combining vocal and orchestral textures with striking melodies.
events.fun_version: This choral piece isn’t just infused with hope; it practically marinated in it! It's like the vocalists and musicians decided to throw a party in your ears, blending their spiritual and orchestral talents into one melodious taco of joy, fuelled by striking melodies!

events.title: Shambala, Concerto for violin, sitar, and orchestra
events.summary: An innovative concerto that blends Eastern and Western musical traditions, creating a dialogue between its soloists and the orchestra.
events.fun_version: Imagine an orchestra and a soloist trying to communicate. It's like a musical version of a phone call on a bad connection - you get some Eastern vibes mixed in with Western rhythms, creating a unique dialogue between soloists and the orchestra. But hey, at least it’s innovative!

events.title: And God Created Great Whales
events.summary: A unique piece featuring taped whale songs, it engages listeners in a profound dialogue between music and nature.
events.fun_version: A unique piece featuring taped whale songs — it’s like a concert where the headliners are whales who forgot their lyrics, but luckily, they still manage to engage listeners in a profound dialogue between music and nature!

events.title: Symphony Etchmiadzin (Symphony No. 21)
events.summary: This symphony reflects Hovhaness's Armenian roots, exhibiting a deep connection to his heritage through its themes and motifs.
events.fun_version: This symphony is like Hovhaness took a deep dive into a pool of Armenian culture and came up with musical treasures! It's as if his Armenian roots and heritage are playing hide and seek in the melodies—and spoiler alert: his heritage always wins!

events.title: Symphony No. 22, City of Light
events.summary: A vivid symphonic portrayal of urban life, characterized by its dynamic rhythms and rich harmonies.
events.fun_version: A vivid symphonic portrayal of urban life, characterized by its dynamic rhythms. It’s like the sounds of urban life got together for a jam session with a bowl of rich harmonies.

events.title: Saturn
events.summary: This poetic piece for soprano, clarinet, and piano explores themes of time and existence, highlighting Hovhaness’s lyrical style.
events.fun_version: Hovhaness's poetic piece for soprano, clarinet, and piano is like if Shakespeare decided to join a jazz band while pondering life’s great mysteries of time and existence! It's a musical existential crisis where time doesn't tick but rather swing dances!

events.title: Majnun Symphony (Symphony No. 24)
events.summary: A deeply expressive symphony that explores emotional depth and storytelling through its orchestration.
events.fun_version: A deeply expressive symphony that explores emotional depth and storytelling through its orchestration... or as I like to call it, an orchestra of feelings trying to tell you a really, really long bedtime story!

events.title: Major Work 'The Rubaiyat'
events.summary: In 1975, he created a significant work titled 'The Rubaiyat, A Musical Setting' which was based on the quatrains of Omar Khayyam. This work has been recorded multiple times, showcasing Hovhaness's lasting impact in the music world.
events.fun_version: In 1975, our hero decided that the world needed a musical masterpiece titled 'The Rubaiyat, A Musical Setting,' inspired by the quatrains of Omar Khayyam. Hovhaness has definitely left a musical footprint so big that you can't help but step in it every time you turn on the radio.

events.title: Guitar Concerto No. 1
events.summary: This concerto highlights the guitar's capabilities, fusing classical guitar techniques with orchestral accompaniment.
events.fun_version: This concerto is like a guitar's audition for a talent show, showing off its classical skills while trying to impress the orchestra—it’s the musical equivalent of a dog learning to surf! It beautifully highlights the guitar's capabilities, fusing classical guitar techniques with orchestral accompaniment.

events.title: Compositions for Indonesian Gamelan
events.summary: In 1981, Hovhaness composed two works for Indonesian gamelan orchestra at the request of Lou Harrison, further diversifying his compositional portfolio to include Asian instrumentation.
events.fun_version: In 1981, Hovhaness decided he needed to spice things up and composed two works for the Indonesian gamelan orchestra— all at the request of Lou Harrison, further diversifying his compositional portfolio. I mean, who wouldn't jump at the chance to add some chiming gongs and wooden percussion to their portfolio? Talk about an 'asian-strumental' extravaganza!

events.title: Symphony No. 50, Mount St. Helens
events.summary: Inspired by the eruption of the volcano, this symphony reflects on themes of transformation and nature's power.
events.fun_version: This symphony reflects on themes of transformation and nature's power—because who doesn't want to sound deep while likening their homework to an exploding mountain? Just wait until the conductor accidentally raises his baton!

events.title: Symphony No. 53, Star Dawn
events.summary: This work encapsulates the awakening of a new day through its vibrant orchestration and uplifting themes.
events.fun_version: This work is like the sun hitting your face after a long night of Netflix binge-watching at the break of a new day, filled with more vibrant orchestration than a marching band covered in glitter and uplifting themes that make you feel like you can conquer the world!

events.title: Guitar Concerto No. 2 for guitar and strings
events.summary: A continuation of Hovhaness's exploration of the guitar, this concerto intricately weaves the instrument with string harmonies.
events.fun_version: A continuation of Hovhaness's exploration of the guitar, which is so intricate it makes the spaghetti junction look like a straight road! This concerto elegantly weaves the guitar with string harmonies together, just like a cat in a yarn factory, creating a delightful soundscape!

events.title: Symphony No. 60, To the Appalachian Mountains
events.summary: A tribute to the beauty of the Appalachians, this symphony evokes the natural landscape through its themes and orchestration.
events.fun_version: This symphony, a tribute to the beauty of the Appalachians, evokes stunning landscapes through its themes and orchestration, but it’s delivered humorously — like an orchestra trying to paint a masterpiece while standing on a wobbly ladder, where sometimes the notes hit the canvas like a bird dropping!

events.title: Symphony No. 66, Hymn to Glacier Peak
events.summary: A contemplative work that pays homage to the Glacier Peak landscape, incorporating themes of nature and spirituality.
events.fun_version: Join us for a deep dive into the Glacier Peak landscape, where we salute both nature and spirituality! It’s so enchanting that even the trees hold more profound thoughts than we do!
